questions.title: Question 1 for Class CLIMATE102_191002
questions.main: How does a hurricane watch differ from a hurricane warning?
questions.answer: When a hurricane poses a direct threat to an area a hurricane watch is issued. When it appears that the storm will strike an area within 24 hours a hurricane warning is issued.

questions.title: Question 2 for Class CLIMATE102_191002
questions.main: What atmospheric conditions cause the forecaster to issue a severe thunderstorm watch? What would be necessary for the same forecaster to issue a tornado warning?
questions.answer: Severe thunderstorm watch: CAPE values of 2500-3500. Tornado warning: a tornado has been spotted either visually or by Doppler radar.

questions.title: Question 5 for Class CLIMATE102_191002
questions.main: How does a tornado watch differ from a tornado warning?
questions.answer: When tornadoes are likely to form during the next few hours a tornado watch is issued to alert the public that tornadoes may develop within a specific area during a certain time period. Once a tornado is spotted  -  either visually or on a radar screen  -  a tornado warning is issued.

questions.title: Question 7 for Class CLIMATE102_191002
questions.main: How does a weather watch differ from a weather warning?
questions.answer: A watch indicates that atmospheric conditions favor hazardous weather occurring over a particular region during a specified time period. A warning on the other hand indicates that hazardous weather is either imminent or actually occurring within the specified forecast area. Advisories are issued to inform the public of less hazardous conditions caused by wind dust fog snow sleet or freezing rain.
